questions.question: Question 1: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
questions.explanation:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group 
antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children 
and show recovery within a month. Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute 
non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary 
hematopoietic disorder. Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition 
that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most 
commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia. Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with 
myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional 
cytogenetic abnormalities.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of acute leukemia?

options.a: Arrest in differentiation and increased apoptosis
options.d: Arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosis

questions.explanation:
In acute leukemia, there is an arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosis. Genomic aberrations create oncoproteins. They arrest normal maturation, turn on pro-growth 
signaling pathways, or protect cells from apoptotic death.

questions.question:
Question 3: As per WHO classification, what percentage of blast cells in bone marrow biopsy is required 
to diagnose a patient with acute leukemia?
questions.explanation:
As per WHO classification, 20% of blast cells must be present in the bone marrow and / 
peripheral smear for the diagnosis of acute leukemia. In FAB criteria, the cut-off is more than 30%.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following conditions does not increase the risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.explanation:
Polycythemia vera increases the risk of developing AML, not ALL. Inherited diseases that are associated with a higher risk of developing leukemias are: • Bloom syndrome • Fanconi anemia • Ataxia–telangiectasia • Down syndrome • Type-1 neurofibromatosis 461 
Sold by @itachibot Other germline risk factors for the development of ALL: • Li-Fraumeni syndrome • Familial ALL syndrome Note: AML has a higher incidence during the neonatal period than ALL among children with 
Fanconi anemia, Bloom syndrome, and Down syndrome.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.explanation:
Precursor B-cell or pre B cell (previously classified as L1) type is the most common subtype of 
acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not a primary T-cell marker?
questions.explanation:
CD10 is not a primary marker of T cells. It is a marker of pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells. Note: Although CD10/ Common ALL antigen (CALLA) can be found in B-ALL and T-ALL, it is 
primarily expressed by pre-B cells and germinal centre B cells. Lymphoblasts of both B and T cell 
lineages, express CD10 that is lost upon progression to a mature phenotype. It is variably 
expressed by a few mature B cell tumours. However, the expression of CD10 by mature T cells has 
not been well established.

questions.question:
Question 7: Block-like positivity for PAS on immunohistochemistry of a bone marrow sample is seen. 
Which of the following cells show this finding?
questions.explanation:
Lymphoblasts in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) show block-like or dot-like PAS positivity. Erythroblasts in acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) show diffuse periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) 
positivity. The image given below shows dot-like positivity for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) in lymphoblasts. 462 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following cells does not stain positively with Sudan black?
questions.explanation:
Lymphocytes do not stain positively with Sudan black dye. Although some positivity may be seen 
in azurophilic granules of lymphoblasts. Sudan Black B (SBB) is a lipophilic dye that binds irreversibly to an undefined granule component 
in granulocytes, eosinophils, and some monocytes.

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the most commonly affected gene in patients with T-cell acute lymphoblastic 
leukemia?
questions.explanation:
The most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is NOTCH1. B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with mutations of genes such as PAX5, E2A, and 
EBF. It may be associated with balanced t(12;21) involving the genes ETV6 and RUNX1.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia is found to have t(9;22). What will be the size of 
BCR-ABL fusion protein produced?
questions.explanation:
The size of BCR-ABL protein in t(9;22) associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is 190 
kDa. BCR-ABL fusion transcript protein with t(9;22): • Major BCR (M-BCR) 210 kDa size in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with weaker tyrosine 
kinase activity • Minor BCR (m-BCR) 190 kDa size in acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( ALL) with stronger tyrosine 
kinase activity 463 
Sold by @itachibot • Micro BCR (-BCR) 230 kDa size in myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) with 
exuberant neutrophilia

questions.question:
Question 11: On immunophenotyping of a patient with early pre-B acute leukemia, which of the following 
marker will be negative?
questions.explanation:
Cytoplasmic immunoglobulins and CD10 are negative in early pre-B acute leukemia but become 
positive in pre-B ALL.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of acute 
lymphoblastic leukemia? 457 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker 
for thymoma. Tdt, CD1a, and CD3 are markers of ALL.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale 
and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given 
below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear 
chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic 
leukemia. ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include: • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, 
splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, 
lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

questions.question:
Question 14: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L 
with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The 
bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this 
patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate? 458 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of T-cell acute lymphoblastic 
leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell 
phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive). The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small 
inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt 
stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms. 464 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical features of ALL include: • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, 
splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, 
lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

questions.question:
Question 15: In a patient with acute leukemia, the immunophenotype pattern of the blasts is positive for 
CD10, CD13, CD19, and CD33. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) based on 
immunophenotyping. CD10 and CD19 are markers for B-cell lineage and this patient most probably have B-ALL. 
Although CD13 and CD33 are myeloid antigens, their expression does not exclude the diagnosis of 
B- ALL. Option B: The diagnosis of mixed phenotypic acute leukemia (MPAL)/ acute leukemia of 
ambiguous lineage (ALAL) (previously known as biphenotypic leukemia) requires a demonstration 
of multiple lineages in blast cells. According to WHO's latest update (2022), the requirements for 
assigning more than one lineage to blast cells are : In the absence of MPO or evidence of monocytic differentiation, expression of CD13 and CD33 is 
not sufficient for a diagnosis of MPAL. Hence, biphenotypic leukemia is not the answer here. B cell lineage 
CD19 strong:1 expressed CD 
10, CD22, CD79aCD 19 weak: 
 2 or more strongly expresse 
d CD10, CD22, CD79a T cell lineage 
CD3 positive Myeloid linea

onocyte differentiation (non- 
specific esterase, CD11c, CD1 
4, CD64, lysozyme)

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with weight loss and fever is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which 
of the following is a good prognostic indicator of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of t (12;21) indicates a good prognosis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It 
involves genes ETV6 and RUNX1. Conversely, a translocation involving the MLL gene, t(9;22), and hypodiploidy are associated with 
a bad prognosis. 465 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: Bone marrow biopsy of a patient shows > 20% immature blasts with scanty cytoplasm, no 
granules, and inconspicuous nucleoli. They also stain positive with PAS. Which of the 
following are good prognostic markers of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given bone marrow biopsy report is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The 
good prognostic markers of ALL include trisomy 7, hyperdiploidy, and age of 5 years. 466 
Sold by @itachibot Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)
